thread.title: Calgary Flames look to find their game in time to welcome The Great 8
thread.title_full: Calgary Flames look to find their game in time to welcome The Great 8

title: Calgary Flames look to find their game in time to welcome The Great 8
text:
Last game, it was the newest generational player who torched the Calgary Flames. 
Up next for them is a player who’s torched the league for the last decade. 
And if the Flames don’t get their act together, you bet Alex Ovechkin and the rest of the Washington Capitals will light up the Saddledome when they meet Tuesday night (7 p.m., Sportsnet 360/Sportsnet 960 The Fan). 
But the Flames’ focus is more about themselves right now, not out of disrespect to Ovechkin — who’s netted eight goals and 17 points in 10 meetings — but Calgary’s hockey heroes must put their game on the right track, having collected just one win in five mainly sub-par outings to start the season. 
“It’s been a bad start. There’s no sugar-coating it,” said captain Mark Giordano. “It hasn’t been good. But sitting here today, we’re still in position we can get some points and get back in it. We’ve got to play with a higher level or energy and compete and we’ll be fine.” 
Only a couple of weeks into the season and already the Flames are facing the reality their season could be slipping away in a hurry. 
Fortunately, they know the issue to solve is pretty simple: They’re not playing with enough urgency and determination. 
“We came in real hungry last year and had that us-against-the-world-type attitude,” said forward Joe Colborne, who’s nearing a return from a pre-season broken thumb. “I think we’ve seen it in spurts, but it’s tough. Watching those games, I didn’t really recognize our hockey team sometimes.” 
The whips appear out, with Monday’s practice at the WinSport facility at Canada Olympic Park very intense and business-like. 
Obviously, they all know there’s a job to do. 
“We know we’re better than this. We can hold ourselves accountable and need to,” said head coach Bob Hartley, who also has mixed up his top two lines. 
“It’s always about being urgent. Everything we do, it’s about being urgent. We just have to get back to our good habits, get back to our preparation and we’re gonna be fine. No one feels sorry for us and no one will do it for us. We’re on our own.” 
But Hartley’s formula isn’t just to put his players through harder paces. 
He’s decided to separate Jiri Hudler from Johnny Gaudreau and Sean Monahan, opting for him to skate with Sam Bennett and Mikael Backlund. In turn, Michael Frolik skated on right wing with Gaudreau and Monahan. 
“After many years of (marriage), sometimes a weekend off is good,” Hartley said. 
That said, changing up the lines will be akin to re-arranging the deck chairs on the Titanic if the Flames don’t find what’s missing from their game and find it in a hurry. 
“Right now, there’s a lot missing,” Bennett said. “We’ll have a couple good shifts but I think just overall there’s not enough compete and there’s not enough effort from all the guys, including myself. I think everybody has to be better. 
“This game is gonna be huge, just to prove we’re gonna respond and we’re gonna bounce back from the bad start we’ve had,” he added. “We’ve got to play a lot more hungry and a lot more aggressive, and there’s no doubt in my mind you’re gonna see that Tuesday.”
